If you placed the Earth on a 10-pound table, how much would the Earth weigh on the table?
Answer: 10 pounds. This is the same as placing a 10-pound table upside down on the ground. The weight is between the Earth and the table, so there is not a separate weight for the Earth and for the table. Weight is the gravitational force, it is not the mass.

a few people are confused about scientific notation. So, let me give a quick crash-course. Scientific notation is properties of "10^n"; that is, we plug in a number for that "n", which in turn represents a product (they tend to be really big or really small). Let me give you an example where scientific notation can be really helpful.


E.g. 5 trillion x 2.3 billion =?

rewrite as: (5.0 x 10^12) x (2.3 x 10^9)

multiplication is communitive (that is, orientation of variables in an expression doesn't matter) so we can multiply the numbers attached to their "10^n's". 5 x 2.3 = 10.6. As the bases are the same, we can simply add exponents without changing the 10, so we get 10.6x10^21, in which 1.06x10^22 would be proper notation. It's really easy math. You could solve this kind of question much faster in your head than the time it takes to punch it into a calculator. Hope my crash course in algebra 1 helped anybody, lol

Actually your mass is in kilograms. Weight is the force of gravity working on your mass. Gravitational force (F) = Mass (m) multiplied by the acceleration you experience in a free fall (g). g is constant and is not to be confused with G. g=9,81m/s². m is your mass in kilograms. F is your weight in Newton. To give an example: m= 100 kg then F=100 x 9,81 so your weight would be 981 newton. Hope this helps :p
